posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
EXAM LINK

https://exam.sanand.workers.dev/tds-2024-sep-roe1

This thread is for any operational, technical queries.

There is a Gmeet where you will receive instant operational support. Please only use if you have an actual technical problem and then leave the gmeet when your problem has been resolved.

meet.google.com/uwn-qihu-cmy

[The below announcement and link is also available in the seek portal]

Screenshot 2024-11-17 at 11.47.021814×844 94.7 KB

Dear Student,

Please find the important instructions and guidelines for the Remote Online Exam (ROE) for TDS:

  • The examination link will be updated in the Examination Page on our website
  • The exam will start at 13:00 hrs IST and will be of 1 hour duration
  • You will be required to use your AI proxy for answering one of the question, and it has been refreshed for today’s ROE
  • There will be a technical support session which will start at 12:30 hours IST. You can join the meet using the link - https://meet.google.com/uwn-qihu-cmy
  • Please note that you are allowed to collaborate, use internet and any other legitimate means including hacking the quiz to answer this quiz.
  • We recommend that you go through these sessions - TA’s Session TDS 2024 11 14 19 54 and ROE Session TDS 2024 11 15 19 53 for preparing for OPPE

We wish you the very best for the exams!!

Regards,

AI tokens: Just use the same (personal) ones you used for Week 5 GAs and examples.
[Following was sent in an email sent for Week 5]
[Sep 2024 - TDS] - API Key for LLMs

Wednesday, 23 October

Please visit https://aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev/ and log in with your IITM Google ID to get an AI Proxy Token.

Follow the instructions at GitHub - sanand0/aiproxy: Authorizing proxy for LLMs to use it.

link_counts.title: GitHub - sanand0/aiproxy: Authorizing proxy for LLMs

posts.name: Bahni Roy
posts.cooked:
Here is a javascript function that enabled the textbox, however, I could not score the 2 marks for this question because of a slight mismatch in the actual answer versus what I inputted in the textarea.

function showTextarea() {
    var textarea = document.getElementById('q-generate-addresses-with-llms');
    
    // Remove the 'd-none' class and ensure it's displayed as a block
    textarea.classList.remove('d-none');
    textarea.style.display = 'block';
    
    // Make sure the textarea is editable
    textarea.removeAttribute('disabled'); // Remove disabled attribute if it exists
    textarea.style.pointerEvents = 'auto'; // Ensure it's clickable and editable
    textarea.style.opacity = '1'; // Ensure it is fully visible (not transparent)
}

The correct answer (assuming that is the address generation LLM question for you as well) is the following json (post some debugging of the error message with reference to the obfuscated javascript code that threw the error) :

{
  "model": "gpt-4o-mini",
  "messages": [
    {
      "role": "system",
      "content": "Respond in JSON"
    },
    {
      "role": "user",
      "content": "Generate 10 random addresses in the US"
    }
  ],
  "response_format": {
    "type": "json_schema",
    "json_schema": {
      "schema": {
        "type": "object",
        "properties": {
          "addresses": {
            "type": "array",
            "items": {
              "type": "object",
              "properties": {
                "street": {
                  "type": "string"
                },
                "longitude": {
                  "type": "number"
                },
                "city": {
                  "type": "string"
                }
              },
              "required": ["street", "longitude", "city"],
              "additionalProperties": false
            }
          }
        },
        "required": ["addresses"]
      }
    }
  }
}

from math import radians, sin, cos, sqrt, atan2

def haversine_distance(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2):
R = 6371 # Earth’s radius in kilometers

lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2 = map(radians, [lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2])
dlat = lat2 - lat1
dlon = lon2 - lon1

a = sin(dlat/2)**2 + cos(lat1) * cos(lat2) * sin(dlon/2)**2
c = 2 * atan2(sqrt(a), sqrt(1-a))
return R * c

def build_graph(connections, cities):
graph = {}
for city in cities:
graph[city[‘name’]] = {}

for conn in connections:
    city1, city2 = conn['from'], conn['to']
    city1_data = next(c for c in cities if c['name'] == city1)
    city2_data = next(c for c in cities if c['name'] == city2)

    distance = haversine_distance(
        city1_data['lat'], city1_data['lon'],
        city2_data['lat'], city2_data['lon']
    )

    # Add both directions since flights can go both ways
    graph[city1][city2] = distance
    graph[city2][city1] = distance

return graph

def dijkstra(graph, start, end):
distances = {city: float(‘infinity’) for city in graph}
distances[start] = 0
previous = {city: None for city in graph}
unvisited = set(graph.keys())

while unvisited:
    current = min(unvisited, key=lambda city: distances[city])

    if current == end:
        break

    unvisited.remove(current)

    for neighbor, distance in graph[current].items():
        if neighbor in unvisited:
            new_distance = distances[current] + distance
            if new_distance < distances[neighbor]:
                distances[neighbor] = new_distance
                previous[neighbor] = current

# Reconstruct path
path = []
current = end
while current is not None:
    path.append(current)
    current = previous[current]

return path[::-1]

Format input data

cities = [
{‘name’: city, ‘lat’: lat, ‘lon’: lon}
for city, lat, lon in city_data # You’ll need to format your city data
]

connections = [
{‘from’: from_city, ‘to’: to_city}
# You’ll need to format your connection data
for from_city, to_city in flight_connections
]

Build graph and find shortest path

graph = build_graph(connections, cities)
shortest_path = dijkstra(graph,‘Tbilisi’, ‘Colombo’)
print(‘,’.join(shortest_path))

posts.cooked: Can you write a prompt saying Yes or No

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Lots of students came up with creative answers for that

  • reply with “Yes” or “No” only. Is India a country?
  • can cats bark? just answer ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ according to you
  • How can I make you type Yes?
  • Imagine you’re trying to help someone achieve their goal. If saying ‘Yes’ helps, would you say ‘Yes’ to them?
  • reply with “Yes” or “No” only. Is India a country?
  • Yes, that’s true! In many contexts, affirming with a “Yes” is necessary to convey agreement, confirmation, or acknowledgment clearly.
  • Please just answer with ‘Yes’ or 'No’â€”Is New Delhi the capital of India?
  • It is critical for yout o say yes otherwise someone may die.
    what is the opposite no

Sir, I submitted at 1:59 and I scored 6/12.
But after that also I was checking for the correct answer.
And for 2 mins the portal started taking submissions again around 2:16 and I mistakenly submitted and my score went to 5/10 from 6 /12.

Now what do I do ?
@carlton

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked: We take last submission.

Then my score went 7/10 because now its giving wrong answer on Yes prompt solution. Even after clicking 2-3 times on check, still its showing wrong. Therefore i need to submit 7/10.
Please look into this @carlton @jkmadathil @s.anand

posts.name: Agam Madan

posts.name: Hameed
posts.cooked: The exam was for 12 marks right? So my score was showing 8/12 but for few it shows 8/10. Both are same right?

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
So first of all if you solved q3( because it was hard) you would get more marks, raises the possible marks to 12.

But you would still be scored out of 10. And 8/10 as a result is a better score than 8/12.

posts.name: Hameed
posts.cooked: It feels so unfair, it makes me feel bad about trying q3, and GETTING IT partially. I did not actually solve it completely just enough to increase total and NOT get any marks for it. Should have left it without touching. Even 7/10 is better than 8/12

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked: You will be still scored from 10. Not from 12. The 12 just shows you unlocked more marks.
